awd_titl_txt: Photon- and Electron-Driven Atomic Collision Processes: General Theory and Accurate Numerical Calculations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project deals with the interaction of light (mostly lasers) and charged particles (mostly electrons) with atoms and ions. The results are of importance for the understanding of fundamental collision dynamics, and they also fulfill the urgent practical need for accurate atomic data to model the physics of stars, plasmas, lasers, and planetary atmospheres. The short-pulse intense-laser part of the project requires accurate solutions of the time-dependent Schroedinger equation on a numerical space-time grid. With the rapid advances currently seen in computational resources, such studies can now be conducted for realistic, as opposed to idealized, model systems. This work is important to facilitate further developments in the imaging and control of submicroscopic reactions, which in turn are expected to have broad impact by reaching out from physics to chemistry and ultimately biology. Another topic is quantum entanglement created in electron-atom collisions.  This area has potential for applications in quantum information technology.  Many experimental efforts worldwide are supported through the present project, which will also train a post-doctoral associate and a number of research students.

Most of the numerical calculations will be based upon the non-perturbative R-matrix (close-coupling) method using a highly flexible B-spline implementation with non-orthogonal orbital sets, as well as direct solutions of the time-dependent Schroedinger equation using various grid-based approaches and basis-function expansions. For single and double ionization of complex atoms by intense atto/femto-second laser pulses, the methods will be combined in such a way that individual parts of the "big problem" can be treated in highly efficient and optimized ways. One example is the use of time-independent multi-electron Coulomb and dipole matrix elements from the B-spline R-matrix method in a propagation scheme for the solution of the time-dependent Schroedinger equation in a few-cycle laser pulse.  This general strategy will be extended to the treatment of double ionization involving inner shells.  Much emphasis will be placed on the testing of numerical methods and the visualization of the results, both of which are ideal for student involvement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We perform benchmark theoretical and numerical studies of collisions of photons (light), electrons, and other charged particles with atoms and ions and subsequently interpret the results. Most of our work deals with ultra-short, intense-field laser--atom interactions as well as electron--atom collisions. An important aspect is quantum control with specifically designed laser and/or electron beams to produce or enhance outcomes that might be desirable but would not occur without special preparation.

We continue to develop both the general theory and the numerical algorithms, and subsequently the associated computer codes, for state-of-the-art numerical calculations.  Our work is important for fundamental research in the areas of light--matter and charged-particle--matter interactions as well as many applications, particularly in plasma and astrophysics.  There data from our calculations are frequently used in modeling, for example, the energy transport in various environments.  An indication of our impact on many projects worldwide is the large number of collaborations we maintain with groups in North America, Europe, Asia, and Australia.

Over the course of the funding period, two post-doctoral researchers, one visiting graduate student, and five Drake undergraduate students participated in various projects. One of the post-doctoral researchers just started at her own tenure-track position while three of the students that graduated from Drake are now in graduate programs at top-level universities (Stanford, CU-Boulder/JILA, Minnesota).  All these participants were able to significantly increase their knowledge regarding various aspects of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics, including the treatment of challenging problems through the use of supercomputing facilities provided by the NSF-supported eXtreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment.

A total of 36 papers in peer-reviewed scientific journals were published during the funding period.  In addition, the principal investigator and both post-doctoral researchers gave 6 invited talks as various international conferences -- some in person, some virtually due to COVID-19 restrictions.  The students also had opportunities to present their work through contributed talks and posters at the annual meeting of the Division of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics and at a special symposium on undergraduate research organized by the Division of Laser Science.
